reviewText: Broken Sword: Director’s Cut does a lot of the little things wrong. Back in 1996, the player was thrown out into a graphic noir world very much like our own, one brimming over with unique personalities who don’t think of themselves as cogs in a giant machine, but people getting suitably annoyed at the pushy American who won’t stop showing people the soiled tissue he found in the sewers and asking them if it means anything to them. Now updated, a lot of the dialogue options are cut in an attempt to streamline the adventure, making the Templar mysteries a significantly greater focus point, but in doing so, it robs the title of so much of its former wealth. Interactive hotspots are not only slashed in half, but are made instantly visible, taking away the nagging frustration of room-sweeping with your mouse to find them yourself, but also highlighting just how much the new version wants to hold your hand. Including an in-game hint system is understandable: a stuck player only needs visit numerous online walkthroughs should they decide coping with their frustration early is better than the cerebral rewards of working through a puzzle, but gone also are the numerous instances where George could make a fatal mistake. Leave an exclusive French hotel with an important and newly-discovered clue, and fail to remember the pair of Italian gangsters hanging around the entrance, and the last thing you’ll remember before being gifted a pair of concrete shoes and invited for a swim is an aggressive frisking and an insincere goodbye. Now, try and leave through the same door, and George will warn you that it’s not a good idea. Then tells you exactly why!\n\nFull review -- http://www.honestgamers.com/9033/pc/broken-sword-directors-cut/review.html

reviewText:
I love Broken Sword. It's one of my favorite adventure games of all time, I grew up with it. Hearing about an update to one of my favorite games made me weary but I remained optimistic. Naturally, I tried to like it. But I just can't.

This revision completely butchered the original on so many levels; it's a disgrace. I am majorly disappointed with how this was handled.
The new arc doesn't bring anything new or interesting to the table (especially if you never played the original before, newcomers get nothing out of this new story) and seems unnecessarily tacked on. It explores a side story that is negligible in the greater context and waters down the impact of the original story's writing and pacing immensely.
The new environments, icons and character models look really out of place when displayed right next to their by now 17 year old assets which in my opinion negatively impacts the immersion and cohesiveness: the clashing art styles and different asset qualities make the game feel terribly stitched together.
The shoddy new UI (which is optimized for touchscreen devices; use of a cursor feels awkward which is a disaster considering the original is a Point & Click classic), automatically displayed points of interaction as well as the help system make the game unbearable when you are familiar with the original.

Revolution went to the extremes with the handholding which is terribly annoying: everything is pointed out to you and instantly made visible. You never feel taken seriously as a player and it's almost as if the game doesn't want or need your skills to be solved. It rather points at everything with a flashy sign as if you were near-blind.

Sadly, Revolution took the phrase Directors 'Cut' a bit too literally. Removed were details like waving flags, idle animations and ambient sounds but also integral parts of the game like dialogue and entire scenes. The cut narrative aspects break the game's story and writing, which was already impaired by the new sidestory.
The missing details destroy the charm the original used to have, the charm that made players fall in love this game. This content was removed for absolutely no logical reason and is a decision of the developer I can't understand or get behind. Who thought this was a good idea? Cutting parts of your story doesn't do the game's pacing any favors whatsoever.

The most jarring of all the omissions however is that you can't die. This is absolute nonsense.
The original version of Broken Sword had a ton of situations where wrong decisions could get you killed (Video Contains Spoilers). Presumably, this was done in order to save the player from losing too much or all of their progress. Removing this aspect however, eliminates incredibly much suspense and is a case of game design decisions meant to appeal to a contemporary audience causing the loss of a lot of suspense, gameplay, atmosphere and ultimately enjoyment for the player.
If you are curious about the extent of the changes, you can find some of them here: http://www.movie-censorship.com/report.php?ID=254238

Regardless whether you experienced the original or not, use ScummVM to play the original release if you can obtain it (Or purchase it via GOG where you will receive both versions with one purchase) and let this abomination rot in the store. You will get a more polished, detailed and cohesive gameplay experience out of it.
Who knows what Charles Cecil and Revolution were thinking. But it certainly wasn't anything good.

Years before Dan Brown's Da Vinci's Code made headlines for its religious subject, there was another story that had a similar setting even starting in Paris and ending in Scotland.This gem was Broken Sword: The shadow of the templars a point and click adventure game released 1996 and re-released in 2010 for the PC with more content as Director's Cut.

First I'll talk about the main game and after I will talk about the director's cut.The game begins in Paris where our main character George Stobbart is enjoying his vacations.Just as he drinks his coffee and enjoying the Parisian autumn two people enter the Caffe: a man with a briefcase who stops to order a coffee and after a short time a clown with a musical instrument.The clown takes the mans briefcase and leaves his instrument which is revealed to be a bomb which goes off and that's how the game begins.The whole story is about George's quest to find the costume killer, and as the plot advances we find out the whole story arc is about the conflict between Templars and Assassins and the templars called here Neo-Templars are the bad guys(sounds familiar? :) ).Besides Paris, other places you get to visit are Scotland(twice), Spain and Siria, each with its own feel and colorful characters which make this a game a joy to play even after you finished it once.The game has hand-drawn animations which look gorgeous, the voice acting is solid and the music works very well with the whole game.

The original game has from me a 10/10 rating, I find no issue with it, its a great adventure game with great characters and a good story.

Now about the director's cut, after the success of the first game the game got 4 more sequels: Broken Sword The Smoking Mirror, Broken Sword The Sleeping Dragon, Broken Sword The Angel of Death and recently Broken Sword The Serpents Curse.Between Broken Sword 4 and 5, the first 2 games The Shadow of the Templars and The Smoking Mirror where re-released with more content and improvements.The director's cut of Broken Sword starts with Nicole Collard, not with George a day before the bombing of the caffe and is essentially a prologue setting up the main story.The new content is some levels with Nico where we find more about her past.As the main game starts the first problem appears:the sound quality,the new recordings really stand out against the old ones from the main game,and also some of the character designs look worse than the main game which is weird one good example is when the character visits a hotel in Paris and there is one character reading a newspaper in a armchair, for some reason his outline was removed he looks like a black mass of animation.Also, they changed the interface and added dialogue pics at the top corner of the screen with the faces of the characters with which you hold a conversation.

rating for the director's cut: 8/10 the new content is good, but the technical problems really drag down the score, they could have remastered it better, luckily they remastered the second game perfectly and the problems here are not present.

reviewText:
A valiant attempt at updating a classic, but sadly problematic. I loved this game back in the mid-90s, and couldn't wait to play the new, updated version. But, while they flesh out the character of Nico and expand on her background and personal stake in the investigation (an unnecessary change, but fun), they also seem to have...er...forgotten scenes from the original game. Important scenes. Scenes that move the plot along, explain details of the narrative, etc. Were they omitted? Cut for time? Bugged?

EG: In the original, George steps into a hidden alcove in Ireland, and discovers an important clue -- a portrait with an image and a name. But in the Director's Cut George steps into the alcove and then it suddenly cuts back to Nico in Paris; she engages in her own new bit of investigation for a while (completely tangential to the main narrative), and George reappears in Paris not 5 minutes later with only a note in his journal about what he found in the alcove. Why was this changed? What is the purpose of it? They removed a scene CRUCIAL to the main narrative just so they could shoehorn in a mildly interesting superfluous side-story. That could have made a certain narrative sense, it's true, but they didn't alter anything George says or thinks after the scene was cut; he then refers to what he apparently saw as though the player/audience should already have seen it for themselves. Problems like this abound, as do audio hiccoughs -- like when one character is supposed to be speaking, but for no reason the voice-actor of the person they're speaking to is reading their dialogue, complete with the wrong accent and gender! It's bizarre! Did I get some sort of April Fool's Day edition of the game?!?

In fact, the more I look at the art and advertising for this updated version, you'd think George was the shoehorned in side-character! All the focus is on Nico, she begins the game, her personal side-narrative takes precedence over the main investigation, and George just comes across as a bumblin' sidekick. It's surreal -- like an alternate universe version of the game I loved. Why not release a separate game or expansion featuring all this new Nico-centric material? It would have saved them the effort of cutting out the old scenes and bugging the audio and video of the game...

In any event, i cannot in good conscience recommend the Director's Cut. The Nico side-stories help pad out the game, but come at too high a cost.

PS: This game also perpetuates the myth that the Templars were idol-worshipping pagans devoted to Baphomet, a legend which (like Baphomet") was created during the waves of persecution & torture instituted by the French with papal approval in the 14th century C.E. / A.D. This detail will drive historians and even casual enthusiasts crazy

recommended: but it doesn't ruin the game itself. Just be forewarned!"

Short version: 90%One of the most well-known point ‘n’ click adventures games from the end of the 90s, Broken Sword is still an enjoyable story almost twenty years later. It may suffer from blocky animation and dreadful voice quality, but the thrilling plot and the quality of the puzzles will always make it a true classic.

Long version:Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars is Revolution Software’s best-known and probably most successful game, known for its sheer length (easily over 12 hours for a first-timer) and good puzzle balance.

The story can be described as a modern conspiracy theory thriller featuring an everyday man getting drawn deeper and deeper into the Templar myth, while trying to solve an ancient riddle and staying ahead of his murderous pursuers. To do his he travels all over the world from Ireland to the Middle East, aided by a sassy photojournalist and a bunch of stereotypical, yet cartoonishly entertaining supporting cast.

The puzzles are what you expect from a classic adventure game. They are complicated, sometimes convoluted, not too often logical, but if you get yourself in the typical adventure game mind-set, most of them can be passed with little difficulties. (Except the goat. *censored* that goat.)

Although Broken Sword features some exceptional backgrounds and decent animation, it is not without technical difficulties. Especially when it comes to audio: most of the dialogue sounds as if it was recorded in an underground chamber, and none of the actors do a particularly good job. Also, in the Remastered Edition there is an additional prologue segment that just does not fit into the game at all.
But these are really minor complaints compared to the sheer amount of fun one can have with this classic adventure title that is still one of the best of its kind even to this day.

Broken Sword: Director's cut	* 8/10
This is the Director's Cut Of the First Chapter from the famous Point And Click Saga: Broken Sword. I didn't play the original Adventure but I know that besides a graphic update there's a consistent section dedicated to Nico where we'll see some interesting locations and acquire some informations useful to better understand the main quest. As usual we'll be kicked straight into action: Nico has been invited for an interview with the statesman Pierre Carchon, which has just been murdered the exact moment she arrives. George is just a tourist in Paris enjoying a break just outside a local Café which is blown away by an explosion. Their investigations will make them meet and join forces for a common purpose.
I have to say this is the chapter I've enjoyed the most (I've played the first 3, now I'm about to play the 4th) as I really liked the riddles, especially the crypted codes Nico must solve. Another very important thing are characters because most of the people you meet will make an appearence again in the following games which is something I really appreciated (no particular spoiler has been done with this statement). However everything in the game (the characters, some riddles) are not to be taken too seriously as both the protagonists (especially George) and some situations with a few characters are quite silly.
The story is interesting and has few interesting turning points and will make you visit various locations from the world, while the interface we'll use to move in this adventure is a classic point & click setup, with mouse controls, a classic inventory system and most importantly many choices of subjects for dialogues with other characters.

+++Pros+++ NEW SIDE STORY. This director's cut adds a new Section Completely dedicated to Nico, and this alone adds a lot of depth in the story. This section will alternate with George parts giving the game what will be the classic Broken Sword structure that will become a standard in the next chapters, where we play constantly with both George and Nico in separate situations that will later join in a unique context.
PUZZLES. There are some nice and interesting puzzles, though I've been really struck by the crypted code puzzles in nico's section. Sounds odd but I really enjoyed those puzzles.
PLOT. Maybe the subject doesn't shine with originality but maybe that's because I've played it in 2015. Still its story is nicely structured and has some interesting plot twists.---Cons--- ACTIONS REQUIRE ACTIONS. Even some obvious actions or sections are completely locked unless you observe carefully or talk with some characters first, but maybe it's right this way anyways...

reviewText:
This game is a masterwork of how to make an adventure game and one of the very few adventure games that can live up to any classic Lucasarts titles. Top-notch voice acting doing justice to a script filled with laughs, sly wit, and over the top spoofs and in its own way is every bit as good of a narrative as the Dreamfall series.

Once you move away from the story elements Broken Sword shows itself in every way to be a superior game. The inventory system is better, the graphics have been updated, the puzzles mesh with the story, and the in-game hint system both manages to keep immersion intact while allowing the player to set their own level of difficulty, in saying that, it’s still the original content that steals the show.

It's impossible to objectively criticize the first instalment of the Broken Sword series without nit-picking. Perhaps the only fair criticism is that the puzzles are not super demanding even without the hints. However, the sad truth is the most of the challenge to the puzzles in other games comes from bad design, not intellectual sophistication. When all and said and done Broken Sword: TDC is the best adventure game because everything in it just works synergistically to keep the player to keep on playing.

reviewText:
Ah, Broken Sword. I have heard a lot about this series as the years passed and now I had the opportunity to play it myself. Normally not a fan of point and click adventures I have to say that given the age and history of the game I really like it. Some cliché story elements to be sure but what really struck me was how incredibly witty this game can be. I have too many scenes to quote that if I would merely start I would quickly fill several pages worth.
The puzzles also stood out for me. Decoding messages and moving puzzles around in a fashion that I have, to my great disappointed realization, never encountered in any form in any modern game. The puzzles are simplistic in nature but brilliant in execution and are genuinely tricky even for a puzzle veteran like myself.
The hints system is a gem for people prone to getting stuck. It levels small suggestions to more direct hints to giving you the solution outright if you as for enough hints.
The story is nice but in this day and age it's not very original. For me it's the journey to the end that makes the fun part of this brilliant game. The side characters you encounter are most memorable in my opinion. English ladies, Spanish aristocrats, French police officers.
I only really have two complaints about this game. The ending is a liiittle anticlimactic. but my #1 main issue is when switching areas and watching the characters walking around is sooo slooow and gets old very rapidly.

I closing I would very much recommend Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars to friends of classics, puzzles and adventure. I hope you have fun playing. ^_^

reviewText: There's a surprising amount of modern sensibility to this remake of the original Broken Sword.  There's a helpful hint system, interactive objects flash with a small icon, and there are the usual visual and audio upgrades you'd expect.  You'll still run into some infuriating moments of classic adventure game puzzledom, but the hint system is fairly clear and the pixel hunting is, thankfully, kept to a minimum.  The hand-drawn graphics look sharp, but sometimes the speech seems slightly off, as though some dialogue was spliced in using different equipment.  It can be a bit jarring.  For the most part, though, this is a serviceable remake of a classic adventure game, and the story is still a fun little mystery romp.

I am a huge fan of point and click adventure games. This game is no Syberia or Myst, but it has it's strenghts.

What I love about the game is the story line and the hint system. The story is actually engrossing and makes sense - the two protagonists are trying to solve a mystery involving the knights templar, leading the gameplayer down a path to understand their order and mission. reviewText:
Unfortunately this isn't a game I would want to play again anytime soon. As I have understood, a lot of original content was cut from the game and replaced to make the game more storydriven as well as helping you along the way to solve things a.k.a handholding.

~ Good ~

Graphics:
I think they are beautiful for its time. The animation is extremely smooth, the characters move realistic and at times it's hard to think they are built out of simple pixels. The backgrounds are all well detailed and even the background characters have solid animation.

Voice acting:
It's quite obvious some of the voices were re-recorded and others are still old. Sometimes it will sound like someone is sitting in an empty room, with a slight echoing sound to it. Other times you hear that the sounds are clearer. The english voiceacting is fine. Nicole has a lovely voice, but I honestly can't understand a thing she says without subtitles. She has a very thick french accent, so it isn't the fault of the game.

Characters:
I found that the background characters bring most of the fun to the game. Some of them are very weird in a quirky way (the kebab seller) and they are the ones responsible for the funny dialogue. Between the boring story, it was fun to hang around and talk to these characters. I wish there had been more of this and less about the Templars.


~ Bad ~

Story:
I honestly found this one boring, hence why I am reluctant to play it again. I think it was a bad thing to give the story so much focus. As you are mostly trying to find information about it, all you do is listen to people talk, talk, talk, talk, talk... ugh. The ending was also grossly dissapointing. Imagine spending hours upon hours trying to find this one final part and it's not even half of what it was hyped up to be.

Dialogue heavy:
This game relies heavily on you listening to conversations and if you don't snap up the important parts, you are going to have hell trying to solve some of the puzzles. A lot of the dialogue feels repeatetive as you are asking about the very same thing. The “oh so myserious” Templars and everyones opinion on it.

Soundtrack:
I found all the music out of place and some of the special effect sounds got on my nerve. Whenever the characters are experiencing a happy moment, the cheesiest of tunes plays in the background. The music also seems extremely loud compared to the voice acting. I keep the music at 20% and the voices at 100%, yet I still find that cheesy tune overpowering some of the conversations.
Whenever you try to use an object on an area which you'll be able to use an item at some point, a glittering sound is played. I am guessing to help the player find clues, but it becomes extremely distracting and tedious, especially when you have 10 items to try. There's also short tunes playing anytime the characters make a conclusion to something, which also gets quite cheesy after a while. Despite these obvious hints, I found the game wasn't clear at all as to what it wanted you to do. Your only kind of help is a question mark that pretty much repeats the very same question you have, without giving any hints at how to solve the problem.

Lack of interactions:
There really doesn't happen much in the game besides dialogue. Most of the puzzles are solved by listening to dialogue or showing the right item for more dialogue. Sometimes the only way to advance the story is talking to everyone in a different order to get the information you need. And the sad things is, the dialogue about the story is the most boring part of the game. I only had fun when I was allowed to use items in the environment to solve things, or try to figure out how to get past guards without them taking an item from me. Dialogue is 90% of the game and the rest is some puzzle solving.

Awful minigames:
The first minigame involves solving a cypted message, which contains at least 2 names which you have heard maybe once or twice throughout the gameplay. Another terrible minigames involves you having to put roman numbers in order of a message, then click a button, then order them correctly again. All in a specific order. And what happens if you mess up 7/8? The whole puzzle resets and you have to do it all over again! Ugh! And the numbers move slow.

Removed content:
This game has obviously been censured by removing the death scenarios. There was supposed to be a timed action scene with a deadly outcome, but instead George will automatically solve the problem for you. So much for suspense?
It's also dissapointing that once you solve one of the bigger mysteries, the screen just cuts and all you get is George words about what it was. Appearently he picks up an item from a room, but seeing him do so is completely removed, as is everything he does and sees in the room. And this is after solving the tedious roman puzzle! Way to go rewarding the player by removing one of the most important scenes after forcing them through the worst minigame.

reviewText:
I'm writing this review for people who, like me, might look into this game hoping for an adventure game with a decent female lead, or at least co-lead. Spoilers: you're not going to find it in this game.

Gameplay-wise: Speaking as a person who only encountered Broken Sword recently and thus in its newest version only, I found the game passably engaging. The puzzles do make you think and offer a large range of potential combinations, although there are places where it drags because the game expects you to do something completely counter-intuitive and gives no feedback on whether you're doing it right, so you go through every single item and combination thereof, then dialogue choices, and finally click everything before you hit it. The hint system might as well not have existed, since it didn't help me and apparently annoyed previous lovers of the game. The graphics are what you might expect from a decade old game, not really updated but not too terrible.

[Some spoilers] As for the characters, you play as Nico Marlet, who is a fairly decent character, drawn into the murder of her newest interviewee and subsequent meddling into her life, for about 30 minutes out of a 7 hour playthrough. The rest of the time you play as George Stubbart, whose only connection to the whole affair was he happened to be at a cafe when it blew up to kill the man inside, and decided he had to solve the crime for great justice or something. He takes center stage and then keeps it for the rest of the game while Nico sits at her apartment and waits, or seduces someone over the phone, or talks to an archaelogist friend to create a really gross doubly-oneside love triangle centered around her. Also there is a very dubious (consent-wise) scene later in the game between George and Nico, whose romance doesn't really have any substance beyond George thinking she's pretty a few times? So many things seem shoehorned in without proper support. It's both baffling and irritating.

If you want a decent head-scratcher and don't mind a host of gender issues, then pick this up. If you wanted a game which treats its women respectfully, don't do what I did. Buy another game.

First of all: I can't recommend this version of the game unless it's to someone who wants an easy handheld walkthrough (and doesn't mind jarring main character switches and even more jarring character voice changes).

I'd recently gotten back into adventure games (after having grown up playing Sierra and Lucasarts games in the 80s & 90s). Saw this one listed on a couple of top adventure game lists; thought I'd give it a try.

The game begins with our intrepid heroine Nico going to meet with some high-fallutin' Parisien media mogul only to witness his murder. First thing I noticed when I got control of the character? That blue flashing light that indicates things the character can interact with. Helpful at first, but later an annoyance when I realized I was searching the screens for the blue light instead of actually looking at what was on the screen. Really annoyed when I realized there was no way to turn it off.

So I stumbled from place to place with Nico, equally despising and yearning for that blue light, occasionally solving mildly difficult logic puzzles made even easier by the detailed instructions that left me wondering if this coupled with the blue light meant the game considered me some sort of idiot who couldn't figure things out on my own. (I'm playing Broken Sword after having just completed Black Mirror, which gave no instructions on how to solve its puzzles - and therefore left me feeling more satisfied when I did solve them.)

Then suddenly I'm controlling George, an American lawyer who witnesses another murder and even though he has nothing to do with the murder or the case, he decides to get involved. I'm still unsure on his motivations for that (or why that workman didn't stop what he was doing to come help after the bombing! The dude was RIGHT THERE and never put down his shovel... Egads...)

Anyway, the two characters decide to share info, even though so far as I can tell Nico's the only one who has anything invested in all this. From then on the playable character switches back and forth, often when I'm not ready for it (I thought I had more to investigate! Which I guess means I did all the stuff required to move on already...?). And sometimes the game takes me to the next location I need to go instead of letting me figure out where to go next.

I saved my game after playing somewhere in the range of two hours and saw my progress was 25% through the game. That really bummed me out. This was way too fast and too easy. Again, I grew up on adventure games in a pre-internet world. Sometimes I'd get stuck and it'd take weeks or months before I or my brother would have an epiphany and discover what we had to do next. This plays like it's meant to be rushed through in an afternoon, perhaps by people who don't want to stretch their brains too much. So I did a bit of research and discovered this version - the Director's Cut - is actually quite different from the original, in which you only play George (the guy who - so far - has no reason to be involved in this story?!) and there's no blue light and you can die and, ARGH why can't I play that version?!

Well, apparently I can. Now I'll just have to wait for it to go on sale on the other site. Bummer. After I finish Original Flavor, I'll come back and try this one again.

The graphics and animations are just fine. So is the voice-work, except for when suddenly someone else is voicing the main character and trying to imitate the original, or certain lines of dialogue sound like they were recorded in a wind tunnel. Also annoying is having to sit there and watch two characters have a telepathic conversation (their mouths don't move), though I have encountered that in other games I've played, and I suppose the animations would be a pain, especially considering the amount of languages this game was made for.

I can't really say much about the story so far as I've barely delved into it. The whole thing is giving me a Gabriel Knight vibe (which is a good thing!) except not as dark (literally). But I love Templar history and mysteries so hopefully the story turns out to be groovy (and I can recommend this game after getting my hands on the original).

One super-annoyance that I have to point out: past tense. Past tense! Why is everything the characters narrate in the present in past tense?! 'It was a brandy bottle.' Why not: 'It IS a brandy bottle'? And then the 'show-vs-tell' sin of having the characters explicitly state how they feel about something. When faced with entering a sewer, Nico says: 'There might have been clues down there. I was relieved I didn't have a key.' Instead, have the actress 'show' how Nico feels through her line reading of: 'There might be clues down there. But thank goodness I don't have a key.' Except for the too on-the-nose recicitation of their feelings, it sounds like something Humphrey Bogart would narrate in one of his Sam Spade films. It just doesn't work for me here.

reviewText:
So, what can you say about a game that is widely regarded as one of the great classics of adventure games? A game that is often among the top five of various best-of-lists? A game that is held dear by many a gamer around the world? A game that already has been drowned in gallons of words over the decades?

Well, I can say I finished it, I guess... And I can say that I'm having a hard time understanding why Broken Sword is so highly regarded by so many people nowadays. Let me clarify my history with this game though because maybe that'll illuminate my lack of enthusiasm. I did not play it back in 1996 when it was released, nor did I play it in 2009 when the Director's Cut was released for Nintendo consoles or in 2010 when it was released for PC/Mac. No, I played it in September 2013 without any prior knowledge. Now, I'm an old man and I enjoy a Werther's Original as much as the next old geezer, so I generally don't have problems with older games for pure technical or gameplay reasons, as they're the games I grew up playing. And yeah, the graphics are fine, the music is fine, the animations are fine, the sound quality is mostly decent, the controls are fine and whatever else is fine. The puzzles are mostly above average, the voice acting is quite alright and the UI doesn't make me want to vomit.

The problems, for me, are the dialogs, the story and the characters. The dialogs are just not funny. Not at all. But they're clearly meant to be funny, which makes it cringeworthy. George is amassing all his wit in every interaction and let's lose some quip that is just so out of place. It's not only not funny, it's also not tied into the conversation, so he comes across like some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ who constantly interrupts the people he starts to talk to with random and oftentimes even mean sentences. It's really enervating and you start to ask yourself why do these people keep talking to him...

The story on the other hand is kinda meandering from some place to the next and then in the end George literally tells us out of nowhere what it is all about and I wondered how the ♥♥♥♥ he knew that... It's really badly written, which is surprising considering that Broken Sword was always lauded for the writing.

And lastly, at least to me, the George and Nico dynamic just isn't there yet. It gets way better in Broken Sword 2 and especially 3 but in this game they just don't really click, imho. Again, it's really weird since the characters were highly praised back in the day. According to Wikipedia and Mobygames.

So apparently the Director's Cut cuts a lot of content in dialogs, puzzles and areas that was originally in the game. I don't know, maybe the game is really, really cool with intact dialogs and story and the original version deserves its place among the greats but this here does not. Or maybe it is just one of the games that has sooooo horribly aged that nothing of its former glory is left. Like GoldenEye 007 for the N64 or WarCraft 2...

It's worth to buy in a 75% sale just to play one of the classics but you're probably better of buying it from GoG where you get the Director's Cut and the original Version together.

I'd gotten this in a Humble Bundle several months back and never played it. I finally decided to sit down and play through the first level and see if I liked it -- and I ended up playing through about the first 3/4s in one sitting. What's actually one of the best things about this game is that in the director's cut there's an in game hint feature for when you get completely stuck! That to me is the reason this game is a recommend. It doesn't matter if you're good and point and click adventures or not. The in game help guide doesn't spoil the solution at first but simply gives prompts to show you where you may have gone wrong.

In my play through I missed one clue and couldn't figure out why I couldn't move on, having the in game hint system helped me to realize what I had missed without spoiling the rest of the puzzle. I love that! Sometimes I miss really obvious things and with other puzzlers can end up stuck unless I want to cheat.

The story line is sincerely good. I liked the amount of real historical research I felt went into it. Everything felt to me like it was actually plausible seeming. The Knights Templar is a super interesting historical subject to begin with, and this game sets up a continuing story line about it in a very sincere and realistic way.

Also there are journalism jokes. That alone makes this game worth getting.

Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars is one of the most popular point-and-click adventure games made in the 1990's.  Originally released in 1996, the 2009 Director's Cut is an update that adds additional content as well as change some parts of the game, the latter which will be described later.

As a note, while Nico Collard appears in most of the screenshots and in the banner on Steam, the vast majority of the game is centered around George Stobbart.  This is a heads up to those who were looking forward to playing as a female protagonist.  Having never played the original, I can only accurately comment on the Director's Cut version.  It's pretty apparent while playing where the new audio is used due to the difference in audio quality.  The newer audio sounds fuller with less static while the older ones sound a bit quieter.  Fortunately, despite the differences there's no noticeable variations between the voice acting of the same characters, which would've been jarring if there were.  Because this is not a modern remake, the artwork, while beautiful, is noticeably lower resolution, so I preferred to play it in windowed mode.  As another note, playing fullscreen on a 16:9 ratio monitor will leave the game in its original 4:3 ratio with blackbars on either side, which I prefer to a stretched image.  Also for some reason it looks like Nico Collard wasn't completely animated by hand as certain actions will replace her sprite with a 3D model.

Overall the game has solid puzzles and a good comedy vibe to a rather serious plot.   There are many locations to visit and a soundtrack to match, and there is plenty of dialogue and banter between characters.  There is a hint system if you get stuck, but I highly recommend to try your hardest to solve the puzzles yourself otherwise you may spoil your enjoyment of the game.  Despite its age, the game is not dated and is recommended to all those who enjoy point-and-click adventure games.

My wish for improvements in the game would be for more consistency between the newer assets and the game.  Also having read about the differences between the original version and the Director's Cut, I wish that this version would have all of the content available in the original and any differences between the two would've been toggable in the options.  I think these changes would've satisfied those new and old to the game.
________________________

Now onto the differences between the original and Director's Cut.  Because I haven't played the original, I can only comment on the more obvious changes that I've read about.
- It's possible to die in the original game.
- Removal of interactions with many objects in the game. This change is probably due to the nature of the times where people have more games to play and are less likely to continue if they get stuck.  The downside is less dialogue.
If you like good point and click adventure games this one is must.

The UI however - and general control of the game - has been changed. As the game was developed for the wii/ds, certain click/drag puzzles (such as sliding puzzles, or puzzles that need precision clicking) don't work as well with a mouse. While you could quite quickly press the inventory button and drag the item to whatever it needs to be used on, having to move the mouse to do this feels a little clunky - and this is the reason why I can't recommend this game.

In the original, there were a number of places where your character could die, but (I assume at the request of Nintendo) they've been removed.  The story addition is nice, but nothing spectacular - just giving a little bit more information as to characters.

This version of the game is far easier (aside from death being impossible), the game will highlight usable objects around your mouse, and also includes a hint system. A lot of people would apparently disagree with me but I feel like there must be a nostalgia factor that I'm missing out on. Objectively speaking, this game would have been fantastic to experience in 1996. Plenty of witty banter and dialogue, and fluidly animated cutscenes. It's damn impressive how much animation is provided for random interactions that don't even advance the story in any way.

But that's sort of the problem. At first it's not a big deal- there are a few characters to interact with, and a few items in your inventory. It's neat to experience the combination of interactions. Until both categories grow larger and you suddently have to start asking every single person about every single item. Some interactions are over quickly, some take minutes to complete as the NPC tells you something inane. Speeding through interactions can become clunky as you watch your character stumble around the screen with their pathfinding alorithm only to show up at their destination and shrug their shoulders, a way of telling the player 'nope, that won't work.' Fine, but you could have just said that to begin with.

I was absolutely shocked to find out that apparently this Director's cut had substantial sections of dialogue missing. With each syllable of spoken dialogue I pray that the game takes mercy on me and makes it the last. And you guys wanted MORE?

You might argue that the superfluous dialogue is optional. You don't have to ask everyone about everything. Well, sometimes you do. Sometimes when the puzzle solutions are completely arbitrary you'll wander around for ages in hopes of obtaining a relevant clue, only to find that you forgot to use that one item on that one thing that gives you that one other thing. Because why wouldn't you need that one thing. Of course you need to take a tissue full of facepaint all the way to syria, to polish a statue, to sell to a tourist, to get fifty dollars, to buy a cab ride. Never mind that you've been eating, living, and travelling for days on your own budget. THE GAME HAS DECIDED THAT THIS IS CURRENTLY THE ONLY WAY TO OBTAIN THING YOU WANT.

Disclaimer:  I personally tend to eschew point-and-click games, as they tend to rely on you being able to follow the developers' oft-illogical logic when combining/using items.

That being said, this was one of the better point-and-click games I've encountered.  The story was (mostly) riveting, and it helped me overpower my distaste for the gameplay, which did at points require walkthroughs.  However, this game does a decent job at helping out the player, as there's a quest log of sorts to remind you where you need to go, and occasionally you can't exit an area until you've finished everything there is to do there, which prevents tedious backtracking.  Furthermore, there are always indicators of things with which you may interact, which resolves one of the most despicable aspects of point-and-click games: figuring what you can and can't interact with.

TL;DR: A good game, great story (although dialogue is occasionally weak), and clever ways of mitigating the amount of frustrating backtracking/getting lost with no idea what to do.

What can I say about Broken Sword Director's Cut I have a kind of Love, Hate relationship with it. The core game from the original is still good and so is the story it tells. However the Director's Cut adds elements to the game that do not enhance game at all. Nico's side story is interesting but doesn't really add anything to the overall story and is never mentioned again after it is finished. The new puzzles are more minigames than anything else and bring a screeching halt to the story where before it moved very fluidly. Figuring out what to do with the items you had to advance the story in the original was the puzzle itself so you felt rewarded when you figured out what to do. Here most of the new puzzles felt like busy work and just didn't feel rewarding and some of the controls don't work well. Moreover to make way for these new elements parts of the old game had to be cut so much of the sprite animation was simplified, dialogue removed and animation trimmed taking away a lot of the charm.

Conclusion
I want to recommend this game, I really do as at its core its still great but the cut content and the mediocre new additions kills an otherwise great game. If steam gave out the original game with the DC like other places I would definitely recommend it but just the DC on its own, no, pass it up unless you are buying the trilogy pack for the other two games and even then go find a copy of the original and play that to experianse how great that game was..
